questiontext.text:
Amontons' law states that the force needed to initiate slip between two surfaces ($$F_s$$), i.e. to overcome static friction, is a fixed proportion of the normal force ($$N$$) between the two surfaces.

These two parameters are related by the coefficient of static friction ($$\mu _s$$) as follows:

$$\mu _s=\frac{F_s}{N}$$

An experiment was carried out as per the diagram below, where a weight of mass m2 was suspended over a subject's forearm by a section of nonwoven fabric.


The mass of the weight was varied, and the force required to initiate slip was measured and recorded in each case.

Due to the curved configuration of the fabric/skin interface, the normal stress distribution between the fabric and skin is not uniform, and the following equation takes account of this.

$$\mu _s=\frac{2}{\pi }\left(ln\left(\frac{F_s}{m_2.g}\right)\right)$$

This relationship assumes that the fabric is inextensible, and it models the subject's forearm as a rigid circular cylinder.

The results of the experiment are plotted in the graph below. A straight line is produced, which goes through the points (17, 44.697) and (73, 158.993).



Using the information contained within the question, calculate the value of $$\mu _s$$ in this case to 3.d.p.

(Please use this level of accuracy in all calculations within this question)

{1:NUMERICAL:=0.454:0.0005#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
The equation given in the question can be rearranged to give:

$$F_s=e^{\left(\frac{\pi }{2}.\mu _s\right)}.m_2.g$$


Therefore, if a graph is plotted with $$F_s$$ on the y-axis, and $$m_2.g$$ on the x-axis (as above), then the gradient ($$m$$) of this graph will be equal to:

$$m=e^{\left(\frac{\pi }{2}\cdot \mu _s\right)}$$


This equation too can be rearranged, and $$\mu _s$$ is equal to:

$$\mu _s=ln\left(m\right)\cdot \frac{2}{\pi }$$


Giving a value of $$\mu _s$$ = 0.454 in this case.

hint.text:

Think of how the information from the gradient of the straight line graph can be used to answer this question.

questiontext.text:
Amontons' law states that the force needed to initiate slip between two surfaces ($$F_s$$), i.e. to overcome static friction, is a fixed proportion of the normal force ($$N$$) between the two surfaces.

These two parameters are related by the coefficient of static friction ($$\mu _s$$) as follows:

$$\mu _s=\frac{F_s}{N}$$

An experiment was carried out as per the diagram below, where a weight of mass m2 was suspended over a subject's forearm by a section of nonwoven fabric.


The mass of the weight was varied, and the force required to initiate slip was measured and recorded in each case.

Due to the curved configuration of the fabric/skin interface, the normal stress distribution between the fabric and skin is not uniform, and the following equation takes account of this.

$$\mu _s=\frac{2}{\pi }\left(ln\left(\frac{F_s}{m_2.g}\right)\right)$$

This relationship assumes that the fabric is inextensible, and it models the subject's forearm as a rigid circular cylinder.

The results of the experiment are plotted in the graph below. A straight line is produced, which goes through the points (13, 34.739) and (73, 148.919).



Using the information contained within the question, calculate the value of $$\mu _s$$ in this case to 3.d.p.

(Please use this level of accuracy in all calculations within this question)

questiontext.text:
Amontons' law states that the force needed to initiate slip between two surfaces ($$F_s$$), i.e. to overcome static friction, is a fixed proportion of the normal force ($$N$$) between the two surfaces.

These two parameters are related by the coefficient of static friction ($$\mu _s$$) as follows:

$$\mu _s=\frac{F_s}{N}$$

An experiment was carried out as per the diagram below, where a weight of mass m2 was suspended over a subject's forearm by a section of nonwoven fabric.


The mass of the weight was varied, and the force required to initiate slip was measured and recorded in each case.

Due to the curved configuration of the fabric/skin interface, the normal stress distribution between the fabric and skin is not uniform, and the following equation takes account of this.

$$\mu _s=\frac{2}{\pi }\left(ln\left(\frac{F_s}{m_2.g}\right)\right)$$

This relationship assumes that the fabric is inextensible, and it models the subject's forearm as a rigid circular cylinder.

The results of the experiment are plotted in the graph below. A straight line is produced, which goes through the points (14, 37.496) and (83, 173.012).



Using the information contained within the question, calculate the value of $$\mu _s$$ in this case to 3.d.p.

(Please use this level of accuracy in all calculations within this question)

{1:NUMERICAL:=0.43:0.0005#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

Therefore, if a graph is plotted with $$F_s$$ on the y-axis, and $$m_2.g$$ on the x-axis (as above), then the gradient ($$m$$) of this graph will be equal to:

$$m=e^{\left(\frac{\pi }{2}\cdot \mu _s\right)}$$


This equation too can be rearranged, and $$\mu _s$$ is equal to:

$$\mu _s=ln\left(m\right)\cdot \frac{2}{\pi }$$


Giving a value of $$\mu _s$$ = 0.43 in this case.

questiontext.text:
Amontons' law states that the force needed to initiate slip between two surfaces ($$F_s$$), i.e. to overcome static friction, is a fixed proportion of the normal force ($$N$$) between the two surfaces.

These two parameters are related by the coefficient of static friction ($$\mu _s$$) as follows:

$$\mu _s=\frac{F_s}{N}$$

An experiment was carried out as per the diagram below, where a weight of mass m2 was suspended over a subject's forearm by a section of nonwoven fabric.


The mass of the weight was varied, and the force required to initiate slip was measured and recorded in each case.

Due to the curved configuration of the fabric/skin interface, the normal stress distribution between the fabric and skin is not uniform, and the following equation takes account of this.

$$\mu _s=\frac{2}{\pi }\left(ln\left(\frac{F_s}{m_2.g}\right)\right)$$

This relationship assumes that the fabric is inextensible, and it models the subject's forearm as a rigid circular cylinder.

The results of the experiment are plotted in the graph below. A straight line is produced, which goes through the points (14, 34.08) and (79, 145.88).



Using the information contained within the question, calculate the value of $$\mu _s$$ in this case to 3.d.p.

(Please use this level of accuracy in all calculations within this question)

$$\mu _s=\frac{F_s}{N}$$

An experiment was carried out as per the diagram below, where a weight of mass m2 was suspended over a subject's forearm by a section of nonwoven fabric.


The mass of the weight was varied, and the force required to initiate slip was measured and recorded in each case.

Due to the curved configuration of the fabric/skin interface, the normal stress distribution between the fabric and skin is not uniform, and the following equation takes account of this.

$$\mu _s=\frac{2}{\pi }\left(ln\left(\frac{F_s}{m_2.g}\right)\right)$$

This relationship assumes that the fabric is inextensible, and it models the subject's forearm as a rigid circular cylinder.

The results of the experiment are plotted in the graph below. A straight line is produced, which goes through the points (12, 31.888) and (87, 168.688).



Using the information contained within the question, calculate the value of $$\mu _s$$ in this case to 3.d.p.

(Please use this level of accuracy in all calculations within this question)

{1:NUMERICAL:=0.383:0.0005#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
The equation given in the question can be rearranged to give:

$$F_s=e^{\left(\frac{\pi }{2}.\mu _s\right)}.m_2.g$$


Therefore, if a graph is plotted with $$F_s$$ on the y-axis, and $$m_2.g$$ on the x-axis (as above), then the gradient ($$m$$) of this graph will be equal to:

$$m=e^{\left(\frac{\pi }{2}\cdot \mu _s\right)}$$


This equation too can be rearranged, and $$\mu _s$$ is equal to:

$$\mu _s=ln\left(m\right)\cdot \frac{2}{\pi }$$


Giving a value of $$\mu _s$$ = 0.383 in this case.

questiontext.text:
Amontons' law states that the force needed to initiate slip between two surfaces ($$F_s$$), i.e. to overcome static friction, is a fixed proportion of the normal force ($$N$$) between the two surfaces.

These two parameters are related by the coefficient of static friction ($$\mu _s$$) as follows:

$$\mu _s=\frac{F_s}{N}$$

An experiment was carried out as per the diagram below, where a weight of mass m2 was suspended over a subject's forearm by a section of nonwoven fabric.


The mass of the weight was varied, and the force required to initiate slip was measured and recorded in each case.

Due to the curved configuration of the fabric/skin interface, the normal stress distribution between the fabric and skin is not uniform, and the following equation takes account of this.

$$\mu _s=\frac{2}{\pi }\left(ln\left(\frac{F_s}{m_2.g}\right)\right)$$

This relationship assumes that the fabric is inextensible, and it models the subject's forearm as a rigid circular cylinder.

The results of the experiment are plotted in the graph below. A straight line is produced, which goes through the points (16, 43.888) and (89, 198.502).



Using the information contained within the question, calculate the value of $$\mu _s$$ in this case to 3.d.p.

(Please use this level of accuracy in all calculations within this question)
